text:
Hey everyone, I'm putting together a survey about payment methods. It's targeting C suite and founders of consumer facing businesses in the UK and it takes 6 minutes to do.

What do you think is the best approach to getting survey responses? Should I raffle an Amazon gift card and do mass outreach on LinkedIn? Should I pay for SurveyMonkey responses? It's the first time I'm doing this and I'm not sure where to start so any advice/guidance is helpful!

text:
Does anyone know if there's a way to generate a Google calendar event for a GoToWebinar event?

Context: I'm sending a webinar confirmation email from HubSpot that includes each registrants unique "How to Join" link, but I also want to include an option for them to "Add to calendar". I spoke with HubSpot and learned they do not support this functionality with their webinar.

Curious if any of you have encountered this before and have a workaround or third-party app you suggest?

Curious if any of you have encountered this before and have a workaround or third-party app you suggest?

text: Hello everyone - My company often crafts social posts about holidays/events related to our work in life sciences (for example, World Cancer Day). Do you have thoughts/best practices around how to frame advocacy type posts (e.g., supporting patients affected from specific diseases/disorders vs highlighting how our services align with a holiday)? I realize this is a business and we do want to highlight what we are working on, but sometimes it feels a little weird to take away focus from those affected from the disease. I've raised this a few times but received pushback, and wanted to see how others strike a balance between the two focuses.

elements.text: Hello everyone - My company often crafts social posts about holidays/events related to our work in life sciences (for example, World Cancer Day). Do you have thoughts/best practices around how to frame advocacy type posts (e.g., supporting patients affected from specific diseases/disorders vs highlighting how our services align with a holiday)? I realize this is a business and we do want to highlight what we are working on, but sometimes it feels a little weird to take away focus from those affected from the disease. I've raised this a few times but received pushback, and wanted to see how others strike a balance between the two focuses.

text: Where does patient advocacy fit in your brand values and go-to-market strategy?

elements.text: Where does patient advocacy fit in your brand values and go-to-market strategy?

text: It doesn't have a specific mention currently. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: It doesn't have a specific mention currently.

text: Our calendar of holidays and events that we highlight is listed as a tactic, but has many focuses (e.g. clients, recruits, patients (though not explicitly named). So I see myself trying advocate for the patient voice (while getting feedback from our teams that work in those areas to ensure everyone is aligned on our messaging). But I tend to get pushback from leadership on this, which can be draining after multiple attempts.

text: I don’t think it ever hurts to raffle a gift card! As far as Survey Monkey, that will probably be expensive to target like that. SurveyMonkey Audience starts cheap, but it can get super expensive to target like that. For example, I was going to target HR professionals in the US for my day job, and they wanted me to pay $11+ per response! It all depends on how much you value your time vs. just getting SurveyMonkey to do it for you. If you have the time to do the research, I’d do it yourself vs. using SurveyMonkey. I ultimately decided to reach out to our internal email list at work, but you obviously may not have that option.

elements.text: I don’t think it ever hurts to raffle a gift card! As far as Survey Monkey, that will probably be expensive to target like that. I ultimately decided to reach out to our internal email list at work, but you obviously may not have that option.

text:
totally agree with fio. you’ll find a lot of good writers out there. people who can string words together and call them a sentence. you can generally hiring them for pretty cheap.

it’s much harder to find someone who can really think about the topic they are writing about and then distill it down into terms anyone can understand. that same skill is correlated with general strategic thinking. and if someone can think strategically they can figure out pretty quickly that what they are offering is worth good money.

it’s the same with any hiring - the best people know how to get the highest end of the market rate, whether that’s a salary or a retainer. so it’s sort of a fools errand to look for the unicorns that you can underpay and squeeze for a bunch of value they aren’t capturing. i think it’s much better to build a business that can afford to pay top of market and then go find those amazing people and pay them a lot.

elements.text:

text:
Where should product-help questions live? Third-party or on the domain?

On one hand, having it on the domain is good for for both owning the content and tracking it, but it's typically thin content. On the other hand, if on a platform like Intercom, the worry of having thin content on site affecting your site's SEO performance is not there

text:
I think product-help normally lives on a subdomain (eg. help.DOMAIN) because it's easier to manage and setup that way.

That said, a lot of newer apps are finding unique ways to merge product-help within the product experience (eg. loom video embeds, tooltips, etc).

text: Hello everyone - I would love to learn best practices for ramping up and researching for a new very niche, nuanced customer/persona. For example, our company is software for construction subcontractors. Tons a nuances in our customer and their business. Any advice on how to approach this challenge to generate truly compelling and educational content? Anyone have a framework or approach?

elements.text: Hello everyone - I would love to learn best practices for ramping up and researching for a new very niche, nuanced customer/persona. For example, our company is software for construction subcontractors. Tons a nuances in our customer and their business. Any advice on how to approach this challenge to generate truly compelling and educational content? Anyone have a framework or approach?

text: Sit in on sales calls. Lots and lots of sales calls. Or listen to recordings or transcripts if you can't get on calls directly. Listen to enough of them, and you'll start to notice patterns in the questions they ask, the objections they have to buying, their priorities and concerns and blockers - all of that is content gold

elements.text: Sit in on sales calls. Lots and lots of sales calls. Or listen to recordings or transcripts if you can't get on calls directly. Listen to enough of them, and you'll start to notice patterns in the questions they ask, the objections they have to buying, their priorities and concerns and blockers - all of that is content gold

elements.text:
+1 on sales calls.

Also?
Sales Safari
from
Stacking The Bricks
. (here’s a
video they created of it in action
, here’s their
pre-recorded workshop on the topic
Sales Safari is an our audience research method designed based on the field of
design ethnography

. 

Here’s the heart of the Sales Safari strategy:
To learn how people
really
behave, observe them in their native environment.

Rather than cold-calling with leading questions, when you go on Safari, you find your customers online — forums, mailing lists, LinkedIn, blogs, chat, Twitter. You use techniques to analyze what they post and do, and you’ll learn how they talk to each other and about their problems, what they want and need, recommend and hate, buy and share.
All with NO creepy cold-calling and NO spammy cold-emailing.

You just drop in and observe what they’re already doing, in public. They won’t even know you’re there.

Then once you’ve mined tremendous value from Safari, you can use their
actual behavior
to design your product, their
actual words
to write your copy, their
actual questions
to tailor content marketing they can’t resist.
There’s more to Safari than just “reading.”
